messages.subject: Re: clear lacquer
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, in a little late on this thread but this is a Momoyama (give or take) period Heianjo Tsuba with clear lacquer.
messages.messageBody:
Hi all, in a little late on this thread but this is a Momoyama (give
or take) period Heianjo Tsuba with clear lacquer.

http://www.nihontokanjipages.com/personal/collection/heianjo_zogan.htm

And for the lacquer lovers, here is what I think, a Umetada tsuba with
Kuro Urushi, and a lot of it in tact as well.

http://www.nihontokanjipages.com/personal/collection/ko-umetada.html

Cheers

Richard

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] clear lacquer
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks David, interesting! I ll spend some time with the photos... Ron STL ... From: David Zincavage To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com Sent: Monday, July 21,
messages.messageBody:
Thanks David, interesting! I'll spend some time with the photos...

Ron
STL

From: David Zincavage

Sent: Monday, July 21, 2008 2:11 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] clear lacquer


Ron,

Here are photos, at least, of a non-mon-sukashi tsuba, papered as Yoshiro.

http://zincavage.org/Yoshiro1.html

Cheers,
David

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] clear lacquer
messages.msgSnippet: Ooops...forgot we can t post attachments. Kind of hate to post the number in case the seller would be embarrassed. Friendly deal so no need to feel bad about
messages.messageBody:
Ooops...forgot we can't post attachments. Kind of hate to post the number in case the seller would be embarrassed. Friendly deal so no need to feel bad about this but... I'll let that up to him if he wants to reply to Peter's request.

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Peter A Bleed
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, July 21, 2008 1:20 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] clear lacquer



Ron,
Fakes coming out of Japan have emerged as a interesting problem for
collectors. I- for one - would like to see the eBay image of your recent
acquisition. Would you care to post it?
Peter

I've always enjoyed Heianjo (never owning an Onin work that I know of) and Yoshiro
mon-sukashi works. Always like brass inlay on good iron!

To my surprise, I just received what I thought looked like a nice early iron with
brass inlay tsuba, recently purchased of Ebay, my first Ebay purchase in ages.
After 40-odd years I thought I had a good "eye" for such things; just bought a
repro! Yikes! Hope to reverse the deal but must admit that "pictures are
deceiving" at times. Looks like an honest mistake on the seller's part, but it
points up the importance of in-hand study. (I think others spotted this since my
bid was much too low if authentic. Just mentioning this to point out how good (in
pictures only) these repros are today.

Enjoyed this topic of lacquer on Heianjo works. I once owned a very similar (or
same one?) tsuba that was pointed out here. I need to sit down and check some of
my other early tsuba for lacquer.

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Dr. Philip Vos Fellman
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, July 21, 2008 8:42 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] clear lacquer

Hi All:

Heianjo are complex. For a start, most Heianjo (real Heianjo and not Edo period
copies) are Momoyama period or earlier. They were mainly made just for a hundred
years or so, basically the 16th century. The earlier pieces are sometimes called
Onin, but even if you include this group, you still only get the period around
1450-1600. That means that they are old. Many were lacquered. Some were well
preserved some were not. The lacquer is part of the overall gestalt. If you see a
hundred Heianjo tsuba, 25 or so will be lacquered, of which 5 will be in excellent
condition, 10 will be decently preserved, 5 will be in need of varying degrees of
restoration and 5 will be dead.

Cheers,

Shirogitsune

--- On Sun, 7/20/08, bungotakadasword <MuramasaIII@...> wrote:

From: bungotakadasword <MuramasaIII@...>
Subject: [nihontostudy] clear lacquer
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sunday, July 20, 2008, 1:58 PM

gang,
last time i mentioned noticing ' clear lacquer " on most Heianjo tsuba,
people thought i was smoking some good weeds....... ....

Typical response was ........... fire scales

http://www.nihontok anjipages. com/tosogu. com/

how about that ?

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] clear lacquer
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Peter - No problem (attached). The seller was a gentleman about it and settled up with me, as expected. There were multiple photos. Soon after I made this
messages.messageBody:
Hi Peter -

No problem (attached). The seller was a gentleman about it and settled up with me, as expected. There were multiple photos. Soon after I made this purchase another alike tsuba was offered out of Japan (350076519430) which looked very nice, but one that I thought looks newer (to my surprise, of course). I was not trying to get a bargain, but hoped to discover a Yoshiro work in a different (than mon-sukashi) for my study. Oh well, maybe next time. Making SF show???

Ron

----- Original Message -----
From: Peter A Bleed
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, July 21, 2008 1:20 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] clear lacquer



Ron,
Fakes coming out of Japan have emerged as a interesting problem for
collectors. I- for one - would like to see the eBay image of your recent
acquisition. Would you care to post it?
Peter

I've always enjoyed Heianjo (never owning an Onin work that I know of) and Yoshiro
mon-sukashi works. Always like brass inlay on good iron!

To my surprise, I just received what I thought looked like a nice early iron with
brass inlay tsuba, recently purchased of Ebay, my first Ebay purchase in ages.
After 40-odd years I thought I had a good "eye" for such things; just bought a
repro! Yikes! Hope to reverse the deal but must admit that "pictures are
deceiving" at times. Looks like an honest mistake on the seller's part, but it
points up the importance of in-hand study. (I think others spotted this since my
bid was much too low if authentic. Just mentioning this to point out how good (in
pictures only) these repros are today.

Enjoyed this topic of lacquer on Heianjo works. I once owned a very similar (or
same one?) tsuba that was pointed out here. I need to sit down and check some of
my other early tsuba for lacquer.

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Dr. Philip Vos Fellman
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, July 21, 2008 8:42 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] clear lacquer

Hi All:

Heianjo are complex. For a start, most Heianjo (real Heianjo and not Edo period
copies) are Momoyama period or earlier. They were mainly made just for a hundred
years or so, basically the 16th century. The earlier pieces are sometimes called
Onin, but even if you include this group, you still only get the period around
1450-1600. That means that they are old. Many were lacquered. Some were well
preserved some were not. The lacquer is part of the overall gestalt. If you see a
hundred Heianjo tsuba, 25 or so will be lacquered, of which 5 will be in excellent
condition, 10 will be decently preserved, 5 will be in need of varying degrees of
restoration and 5 will be dead.

Cheers,

Shirogitsune

--- On Sun, 7/20/08, bungotakadasword <MuramasaIII@...> wrote:

From: bungotakadasword <MuramasaIII@...>
Subject: [nihontostudy] clear lacquer
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sunday, July 20, 2008, 1:58 PM

gang,
last time i mentioned noticing ' clear lacquer " on most Heianjo tsuba,
people thought i was smoking some good weeds....... ....

Typical response was ........... fire scales

http://www.nihontok anjipages. com/tosogu. com/

how about that ?

milt

messages.msgSnippet: Hi All:     Heianjo are complex.  For a start, most Heianjo (real Heianjo and not Edo period copies) are Momoyama period or earlier.  They were mainly made
messages.messageBody:
Hi All:
 
  Heianjo are complex.  For a start, most Heianjo (real Heianjo and not Edo period copies) are Momoyama period or earlier.  They were mainly made just for a hundred years or so, basically the 16th century.  The earlier pieces are sometimes called Onin, but even if you include this group, you still only get the period around 1450-1600.  That means that they are old.  Many were lacquered.  Some were well preserved some were not.  The lacquer is part of the overall gestalt.  If you see a hundred Heianjo tsuba, 25 or so will be lacquered, of which 5 will be in excellent condition, 10 will be decently preserved, 5 will be in need of varying degrees of restoration and 5 will be dead.

Cheers,

Shirogitsune
